The new phone popped up with a app asking me if I wanted to transferred all my information and apps from the old phone over to the new phone
To be safe I did save a backup to iCloud - then turned off Icloud and Find my phone on the old unit
After about 30 minutes the process completed
Then I moved the Sim card over to the new phone and I had service
All in all it was rather painless to upgrade and I did not have to wait in line at the phone store

This was the first time buying a used refurbished cell phone instead of getting a new one
The reason is simple, the price
The renewed iPhone 8+ came via FedEx a few days after it was ordered, packaged in new box and well protected
The screen already had a glass protector on it but showed no evident scratches
The back of the phone showed no signs of wear either
Came with a generic new, listed as certified charger and cable, did not try those yet
Used an Apple charger and cable to charge it, which was quick
Mirroring the apps, contacts and details from the old iPhone to this one was slick and maybe took 20-30 minutes
It is supposed to come with a sim card removal tool/pin, there was none, but I had one already
Once changed and powered, verified with Verizon rep that the phone was showing up on the network
Battery life is good for a full day's typical use but that can be subjective since everyone uses their phone differently
So far so good, a worthwhile purchase

I bought this phone and gave it a chance, because the price was right, and all of the reviews that I either read, or watched gave the phone (and other cheaper phones from BLU) decent comments based on the price
I went into my purchase knowing that I was a very casual phone user; I use all of the main social media apps: Whatsapp, Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, etc

I understand that it's probably the measly 1 GB of RAM that I was well aware of, but it just isn't enough for what a phone of its size, and timing needs, so for that, I don't think it has a place in the market
The phone itself is VERY nice (not just for the price)
One other issue that I did not see in any reviews is the fact that this phone does NOT pick up LTE/4G network

Great Budget Phone -  Please read to understand
Just received my phone yesterday so this is after 24 hours of reviewing
More reviews of this phone to come later
The Blu G9 Pro is a great Budget Phone bringing great features to the table that you would find in Flagship devices
Screen HD+ is very clean and vibrant
The speed of the phone is right where you would expect however it seems that there are some tweaks in the backend to help along with the MediaTek processor
Like others, I wish this phone had NFC capability but is not a deal-breaker

The cameras are great with some really good photos however the video quality when recording video is not so great, however, there is a silver lining and this mostly due to not the physical hardware but software
Because this phone recently was just released I feel that some software tweaking will help the camera part significantly as you can get different results with other camera apps

Now keep in mind, this is fairly new on the market and so the software side of this does feel a little RC or Beta (as I could tell right from the setup process when Android Setup kept crashing) and feels similar to when Apple releases Beta iOS software as well as Android Beta
I think in a few months once some of the bugs are ironed out and Blu releases updates to this phone

I also noticed a little bit of lag in receiving texts and sending them via the messaging app (not all the time but its there depending on how low your signal is, this could be a carrier issue however as well)

The bottom facing speaker is loud and mostly clear, it does sound like the audio is shooting one way instead of providing somewhat of that atmosphere sound to make it seem like the audio is shooting up towards you (something else software tweaks to Android can do)All in all, build quality is great and bonus case and tempered glass was excellent and very thoughtful from Blu

This was my first Blu device as in the past I felt Blu was always the very low budget phones but it is going to be nice to keep an eye on whats coming out with Blu and how they will compete in the midrange category, I would be very interested in reviewing other devices from Blu
More reviews after a few weeks will be coming

I've been a BLU fan for years, and they've really outdone themselves with this one! The battery lasts forever, the screen resolution and color rendering are excellent, and it's always quick and responsive
This has a few quirks, but it is a lot of phone for the money!
Let me start with the bad stuff
This phone has a few annoying quirks
For one, the volume button does not work right, and it frequently skips a level
The portrait to landscape mode sensor gets set off very easily, so it is constantly flipping me into landscape mode

If you set the screen to turn on when you pick the phone up, then it will constantly be lighting up when it is in your pocket, and you will have to search around until you figure out which setting to change
The speaker is mediocre at best and the headphones that come with it stink - you will need to get some headphones
The screen is not as sensitive as some other phones', but it is good enough
Oh yes, and for some reason the screen dims a lot when I go to look at something, and I have to manually turn the brightness up

And most annoying of all - if I am listening to a podcast or some music and the phone gets an alert for something, like a text message, it shuts off the sound, and then I have to reboot the phone if I want to continue listening
I did not have this problem with my last Android 10 phone
Now onto the good stuff
This is a lot of phone for the money!I always buy unlocked phones, and I do my research before I buy one
This has excellent specs for the money, and you could only do better by buying a phone from a Chinese manufacturer (e
Blu is an American manufacturer and it offers a one year warranty like any good phone maker should
I have read that Blu is merely a front for a Chinese company, but still it is an American business entity, and if you want to find a phone that is made in America or Europe, well, good luck to you
I think even Apple and Nokia buy a lot of their components from Chinese companies
The 5100 mAh battery lasts and lasts
I regularly get a couple of days between charges
The screen is clear and readable, and the colors look fine

It is hard to find a good case for it, since it is a new phone from a small company, so Blu includes a protective case - thanks!There is lots of space and RAM, and unless you download lots of stuff or use huge numbers of apps you should be pleased with the memory situation
I am not a gamer so I have no opinion on that - I just wanted a good smartphone
I have had it for just 4-5 weeks so I can't comment on the longevity, but so far so good
I haven't really checked out the camera yet - I may update my review after I do that, but so far I am happy with the photos it takes
The angle on the lens is pretty wide so you will have to get pretty close to your subject if you don't want to zoom in
Low light photos are better than with my last smartphone, but probably not as good as on a high end phone
It takes 48 mp photos, which is plenty big
If you are a phone fanatic and are willing to spend around $1000 for the latest release from Apple or Samsung, you probably are not even looking at this item
But if you want a phone with good specs for a fraction of the cost of a flagship phone, which is what I wanted, you might be happy with this
So far I am
Best phone for the buck hands down!!

I knocked my rating on this down two stars because of the very annoying system alarms on this phone
It did an automatic reset at 2:30AM the other day
This morning at 7am it did another reset of some kind and made another sound
I have turned off all of the system notification sounds I can find
One would think a company would understand a cell phone is a tool and should not have intrusive features-- especially at 2AM!!!(Or at a business meeting, or in church, or in school, etc etc
But for a basic reasonable-power smartphone, this is a good purchase
The size is great
Reception is fine
It Has all the bells and whistles (too many, actually as noted above) and is reasonably easy to set up
Comes with both a hard-glass protective screen and a rather nice armor-level case
Can't beat that for a deal
This isn't a gamer phone
It can play standard games fine, but has neither the processing power nor graphics capability for high-level games
But it has 64 gigs of memory, so you probably won't need an extra SD card (unless you're in the habit of storing movies on your phone
Don't forget to bring the tiny little popcorn)

The spear of the smartphone world!

The spear of the smartphone world folks!Simple but effective!Lets start with what it comes with outta the box though!It comes with a screen protector, a surprisingly decent case (yes the wireless charging is compatible with it! And so is the screen protector!), wired earbuds (it has a decent range of all three
It also has the usual sim ejection tool, manuals and what not
Needless to say it is a complete kit right outta the box
I will say that the screen protector is about as fragile as an average phone screen however
With that out of the way, elephant in the room time

If you use apps one at a time and clear all of them regularly (closing an app in the menu doesn't actually close it on Stock Android; after pressing the square menu button, press the X within a circle to actually restart everything), it is perfectly acceptable
At most that I could run at the same time is Moovit running in the background and Genshin Impact being actively played
Speaking of which, it can run Genshin Impact up to Medium(ish) settings at an almost consistent 60 FPS
Normally they should be $250
Now for the battery life

Using a mix of games (considering the above, it wasn't exactly light games either!), GPS applications with a mix of them being actively and passively (running in the background), along with Brave Browser usage, and semi-heavy Youtube/Social Media usage,I was at max, able to squeeze out 10 hours of Screen On Time (SOT for short),off of a full 100% charge
I had about 2% of battery life left over still too
If you use your phone lighter than this, you can easily do two days off of a single charge
Easily an all day battery if you always charge it to 100% over bed time
The selfie tear drop does get in the way of game menus sometimes though
It still won't like it if your hands are wet, dusty, etc
Both cameras get the job done
This phone also has expandable storage up to 128 GBs
There's a little bit of bloatware but it can be ACTUALLY UNINSTALLED easily unlike certain high end Android smartphones
Besides the little bit of bloatware that is installed, it is basically stock Android 10
All in all, for the price, it is perfectly acceptable especially at $200
Is it flagship status? No
Is it waAAAAYYY more reasonable of a purchase? Probably
Do note that this phone DOES NOT have an IP rating!I use these to compensate for it:https://www

Disappointed!
I'm disappointed because Blu offers a great higher end phone for a fantastic price, but this one misses the mark
I've barely had it a year, & don't want to spend $200+ to replace it
I feel I'm stuck with it because the warranty is out, & although I should have taken care of it before waiting, I'm now going to need to find another phone
This is the second Blu phone I've had
I loved my first one, & decided to buy a second when it begin to have issues
I purchased the Blue Pro 90, not to use as a gaming phone as it was advertised, but because of its features in general
I wanted the battery life, the storage capacity, & the speed of prices while using multiple apps
I had it about 2 months & begin to see small issues, stupid me, I kept thinking it might be something I was/wasn't doing, & plugged along
The performance only got worse, & now it's been a little over a year, & it's a joke
The feedback you get, such as, 'message sent', 'call ended', etc, stats on the phone, covering your keyboard, function buttons, navagation bar, etc, for 3-5 minutes
Regardless of the promise the battery life is 'outstanding', & can handle gaming, it doesn't
I don't game, at all, but the battery gets warm, with or without the special vented cover it comes with to keep it from doing so
The fingerprint reader barely works, the settings menu is a pain to navigate, the 'search' feature in settings ALWAYS says, 'no matches', no matter how you enter a search
There are practically NO helps or instructions for ANY problem you have, no trouble shooting, etc
He's the IT guy everyone calls to fix computer/phone/tablet issues, & he's generally a fan of BLU, but even he's not impressed with all the promises this phone makes
The settings are buried deep, even some of the simplistic, everyday things, & it lacks a few of the simpler settings my first one had
It's not user friendly for most people I've talked to
If you're just using it for calls, text, general web browsing, & for or five simple apps, you'll fair okay, but I'm an extensive app user, & use my phone for everything

I'm semi-handicapped health wise, & confined to a chair most days, & with all the Covid/health stuff, my phone is important & allows me to pay bills, shop, have access to current issues, & news, & keys me keep in touch with my friends & family

It offers the security of being able to reach my husband when he's working, or help if I need it quickly, & I feel like this particular phone with its seemingly small, but important issues, hinders those abilities a good amount of the time
It has slowed down a call for immediate help, because of the feedback messages blocking my screen, or a hesitation of operation
I don't recommend this phone, unless, as I said, you just want the general/basic functions of text, calls, & a couple of simpler apps

Review of the G90 with Mint Mobile
I was looking for an unlocked phone for $200 or less with decent storage, battery life, and camera to activate with the Mint Mobile network
Phone arrival and setting it up on the Mint Mobile network - Phone arrived with Amazon's 2 day shipping right on time
Performance - I haven't noticed any lag while browsing the internet and playing games
Camera - This was a big thing for me, and the camera met my standards and exceeded them

Battery Life - This phone claims to have a 3 day battery life, which I'm assuming means it'll have a 3 day battery life if you charge it to 100% and not use it for 3 days, because I haven't gotten more than a day out of it
Overall - Still impressed with it aside from the dropped call issue

I have had the following issues with my G90 Pro purchased through Amazon on Feb 10, 2021:1 - Since purchase: I have had Bluetooth issues with the phone often struggling to find and connect with Bluetooth devices that other devices can see
I had this same level of substandard Bluetooth performance with my previous G90

2 - Within approximately 90 days of purchase I experienced intermittent connectivity issues, with this phone failing to maintain a connection or dropping a good signal in areas where my previous G90 phone did not
This issue continued for about two weeks before becoming less noticeable - I believe it has now gone away
3 - Recently, so about four months after purchase, the call audio is failing
When I answer or initiate a call I cannot hear the caller, and sometimes I am able to find them by switching to the speaker
Sometimes I make the call with the speaker and can only hear the call if I switch to the handset, and in both cases whatever mode I use the volume is limited and inconsistent / wavering
4 - Microsoft Teams does not work well on this phone, it crashes the whole phone when launched or when the call feature is used in Teams

Missing critical features for the US market
This phone performs well
The Mediatek G90T CPU handles everyday tasks and even games surprisingly well for such an affordable phone
The screen looks decent, the high amount of built-in storage and micro SD expansion are nice
It does not fully support any US carrier, and VoLTE does not work so when 3G networks are shut down in the next year or so this phone will be unable to make calls
WiFi calling does not exist on this phone either
The description says that new AT&T activations will not work with this phone (this is due to the lack of VoLTE support), leaving T-Mobile as the only carrier you can use
But this phone does not have band 66 or 71 so you won't have service on this phone in many areas even though there actually is a signal there
The phone is also missing several of the AT&T LTE bands as well so even if you can get it to activate on AT&T you will have no or poor service in many areas
The software is poorly made
They didn't bother to provide Widevine level 1 support so video streaming services like Netflix will not play in HD
The volume is unacceptably loud on the lowest setting, and it plays this obnoxious start-up sound that is very distorted because it is so loud every time you turn the phone on
I had to use an equalizer app and just turn down every frequency just to get the volume to a manageable level
Unacceptable

Reviews of these unlocked phones online intended for the American market seem to completely overlook the fact that pretty much all of them are simply missing the proper hardware to make them usable in the United States
Just because a phone is GSM unlocked doesn't mean it will work on any GSM carrier
It's like these people are using the phone on WiFi only and reviewing it based on that

If you want this as a portable gaming device that will be used only on WiFi, or you live in a large city and never travel anywhere, and you never need to actually make phone calls (even in emergencies) maybe this is the product for you
Value Priced Unlocked Phone but No Calls over WFi
This is good value for price for an unlocked GSM phone
Outstanding battery life
There is a big issue to consider before you buy
This phone does NOT support calls over wifi
Consider how important this feature is to you before you buy
Other wise solid performer at a good price

Updated Review

I originally posted a critical review when I had received an email from BLU that this phone was on sale, but when I clicked the ad- only 12 minutes after receiving the email, it had a much higher price listed
This was corrected a few days later, and I purchased the phone
This is my 4th BLU phone over the last 5 years
The g9 developed a charging problem so I have sent it in under warranty for repair
BLU was quick to get back to me with an RA number, so we'll see what happens
The other phones I have been able to sell used for nearly what I paid for them as I use Blu's introductory specials to buy them at significantly reduced prices
The G9 Pro is a flagship worthy phone
An Apple or Samsung phone with the stats of this phone would cost $500-700
It is fast, smooth, and certainly does not feel or act like a cheap phone
I will continue to use BLU phones assuming they honor their warranty on my G9
Tremendous value and the few times I have contacted customer support, they have resolved issues within minutes
Highly recommended
High quality phone for a mid-quality price.
Based on my usage, it appears the battery will last about 3 days, but I don't wander around with my nose stuck in the phone all day
Other reviews have suggested that the cameras aren't at the highest quality, but they sure seem fine to me
It doesn't do 5G, but again, it doesn't cost $800
Bottom line: This is the nicest phone I have ever owned!
Stop thinking, buy it!

Powerful phone on a tight budget, great for emulation
It's still difficult to find a more powerful phone in the same price range
I am an individual who is very well-versed in tech, and I strictly only use budget phones

For the current price of $179, this is an excellent deal: you'll be very hard-pressed to find anything in the same price range with a more powerful CPU or bigger battery, it's almost impossible unless you're willing to go used/refurbished
Some quick pointers after using the phone for roughly a week:- the battery lasts a very long time
The main thing for me is gaming, as I bought it specifically for it's better-than-average specs and powerful processor
For regular games, I play a lot of Minecraft and Bullet Hell Monday
For starters, all of the really old stuff runs even on a crummy $50 bargain bin phone, so I'll just ignore that and focus on the harder-to-run emulators
All in all, I am extremely happy with this device as a portable retro game handheld

Best cell phone I've had
I come to Motorola’s G Stylus after a Samsung Droid Charge (a very aptly named power hog), a Note 3, and a Note 4
After my middle-school son had good experiences with a couple of Motorola budget phones, I had decided I’d try that brand and give up the stylus
Forgetting about the stylus for the moment, this is an incredible bargain for a smart phone
That is remarkable
For that, you get great basic cell phone functionality, more than sufficient speed and storage, and okay (with hopes of better in time) stylus operation
This is the first cell phone I’ve owned that I could charge up in the morning and have last the whole day without constantly plugging it in whenever and wherever I could find an outlet
Reception at the coast has been better than with Iphone 8 Plus and 11 Pro Max phones belonging to other family members
The fingerprint security is spot on
It is also absolutely wonderful to have a phone loud enough to play music or conference using speaker phone without an accessory speaker
The three cameras give a lot of options
I’ve seen a couple of Youtube videos that persuade me the G Stylus will be user serviceable if/when the time comes, unlike some of the lower-end Motorolas
After two months, the few things less than ideal are:- The display has neither the color subtlety or the ultimate brightness that Samsung OLED displays have long had
A lot of what makes me happy with the G Stylus is due to maturing technology and packaging that now allows a well-executed feature-laden budget phone
Unlocked phone with nice features
I've been using a Kindle for several years to check email and get online when I don't feel like sitting in front of my desktop PC
The pandemic and California's fire season were reasons for me to bite the bullet and buy the Moto G Stylus, my first cell phone
T-Mobile sold me a SIM card for the prepaid option I chose, and they've been kind enough to escort me through some of the menus
He checked it out and seemed to like it, saying it had a nice keyboard and the camera lenses didn't stick out in back, which can be an issue with some phones
Learning how to use the Android phone took me a few weeks, but now I'm attached to it and its built-in stylus
It's also much faster than my Kindle
One reason I bought it is because MDHearing aids can be paired to the phone with an app
But I misunderstood what pairing meant
I found I need to use speakerphone in order to hear someone's voice, because only media volume can be amplified beyond what's considered normal
But no matter; I don't like to talk on the phone anyway
I can always use email, I can see my Contacts, and now I can text, which is brand new territory
There are videos that gave me a clue, and I finally figured out how to move non-fancy photos onto my 256 GB microSD card
I don't use the fingerprint reader because what if I get injured?Using a password is what I'm used to, and the phone lets me do that
I ended up buying a notebook-type holder for the phone, which is said to be rather fragile
A harder case including a Gorilla-type facing that was supposedly designed for this phone interfered with my being able to get to all of the buttons
No other reviewers mentioned having that problem
At that point I barely knew how to turn the phone on, so maybe it was just me
Evidently this phone only does a fast charge, which is not my preference
Online research told me that slow charging is easier on a phone and that's it's best not to let a battery go to zero and not to charge it to 100%
The article was a few years old, so maybe things have changed
The special charger gets hot, then cools when the phone gets to 100%
Full charging happens in just a few hours, and I'm not always quick enough to unplug it before 100%
Do I need to worry about full vs
I'm still a newbie
I hope more comments show up to answer my questions

No more Samsung flagship for me!!
I've been a Samsung Galaxy owner from the beginning
I've owned an s1,s3, and can s6
When my last phone began to really lose its functionality, I started looking again at Samsung's flagships again
Super pricey, but it's what I know
My brother picked up a moto G stylus and recommended it
Several days of research, trying to make a decision on whether to spend a thousand dollars and stay in my comfort zone or try something new for a couple hundred dollars
I'm satisfied completely and saved several hundred dollars and still upgraded from my s6
It does everything I need it to do
There is a very sight lag by comparison to other note phones, but it's hardly a dealbreaker
My primary reason for wanting a stylus was for work notes, and it works well enough
The only issue I have (and my bro) is that when USBc cable is attached for charging or file transfer, the stylus is almost unusable
Some kind of bug, but really, you don't need to keep it married to the charger because the battery life is phenomenal so it's never really an issue
I rarely have a concern about battery life and I use it constantly for music, videos, browsing and reading
I don't even need to keep it plugged in when I go to bed at night, as I'm confident I'll still get all of tomorrow out of it
Another standout feature really are the built in speakers on this thing
They actually do sound really, really good
Beyond my expectations
Fingerprint scanner works so much better and more consistently than my s6 ever did
What a joke
I also love some of the gestures, mostly the twist to summon the camera on demand, and a quick shake to turn the flashlight on/off
I love it, super easy
Built in storage is high, sd card slot available for even more storage, using previous Verizon sim worked just fine
I highly recommend this phone on a budget, but also even if you're not
A few hundred bucks can go somewhere else in your life
I work in construction, and the best part about this phone is that if it takes a beating or gets broken, worst case I'm out $200, not $1000+
The things that had me concerned about this phone based on reviews, really weren't a big deal unless you insist on cutting edge quality that most people just wouldn't notice
For work I need a good camera, note taker, a nice and large display to show pictures to clients, battery life, and good sound for music playback
It is possible that this phone lacks features you absolutely must have so keep doing your research

Hard to beat for the price - I love this phone
I bought this as a backup phone and I'm shocked at how good it is
What I liked more about the Stylus than the OnePlus:The flat screen that allowed me to easily apply a glass screen protector

The fingerprint reader on the back of the Stylus is much better than the OnePlus because it worked every time! The OnePlus fingerprint reader is much too finicky and will not work if my skin is too dry (a constant problem with all the hand washing these days)
The Stylus has a front facing camera hole in the screen, which I prefer over the popup camera on the OnePlus
Other things I really liked about the Stylus:The Stylus has a generous 128GB of storage and expandable storage
The 4GB of RAM is barely enough and I did notice a little stutter when scrolling through news articles
I don't know a lot about the screen, but I found it more than good enough for me
I'm not a camera critic and this one seemed more than good enough for me
The only other drawback was the lack of 5G on T-Mobile, which is somewhat new
So all in all, I almost like this economy phone as much as a much more expensive, high-end phone

While I was expecting a much better experience after a badly needed upgrade to a modern smartphone (from a Le Eco S3), I'm still impressed by the Moto G Stylus
Virtually everything is smooth and responsive (though the Amazon app is still a hog), and the battery life is exceptional
After a full day of heavy (though non-demanding) usage, I still have plenty of power to spare
Android 10 is quite nice, particularly the gesture navigation, though some may want to lower the sensitivity to avoid accidentally triggering a back command
The physical gestures to open the flashlight and camera are handy and unique

A couple of minor issues aren't enough to drop my rating by a full star, but the most noticeable is that the left bezel obscures a few rows of pixels, so on a page with very small margins, the bezel could obscure the leftmost letter in each line, or small elements that are flush with the left edge of the screen might be hidden unless you tilt the phone and look under the bezel
Comparing with the Moto G power, and yes it DOES work with Verizon Prepaid.
Compared to the Moto G Power which I first bought and returned, the Stylus 2020 wins, hands down
VERY happy with its 4000mAh battery's run time even though it’s 1000mAh less than the G Power
It has double the storage at 128G vs
Though I did not think I would use the stylus pen, I'm finding I love it for marking up a screenshot or when precision is helpful
As for screen clarity, it’s crisp
Colors are good saturation though not exceptional
Cannot speak fingerprint or facial recognition, I won't use either
The stereo speakers only operate the lesser quality bottom speaker when using speakerphone on calls, so the other person's voice sounds annoyingly canned and tinny and sometimes grating
Direct-to-ear call quality is as it should be but I avoid that so for me, the speakerphone is going to remain a real trade-off
But that’s the only drawback to the Moto G Stylus 2020, or perhaps just to phones with stereos speakers
In all other ways I’m finding the 2020 Moto G Stylus to be a mega value for anywhere near its price range

Camera is good, nothing like apple, but a lot better than the z2 force
I really liked the feel of the z2 force, slim and light cause I never used a case, just screen protector to keep from scratching the plastic screen
The stylus is heavy and clunky, and I put a case on it hoping the bumpers of the case will protect the screen from drops, and it is overly thick
I probably should just get a screen protector and use no case when I need to go out
I wanted a little extra size on watching videos, but it is the same size as the z2 force

The z3 play has a larger video size due to it being wider which I had hoped for, but the screen is crisp, and good, and I used developer options to set pixel width to 552, and set all text to small, so a lot of information can show up on the screen which is great

I have boost mobile phone service and yes its compatible on their network
I did my research and I knew exactly what I needed to make it work
I bought Sprint UICC Sim Card Triple Punch SIMOLW516TQ
Call the boost mobile customer service
You cannot do it online at their website because it does not fall within compatible list of phone
You must call
The tech on phone will asked you give them your Integrated Circuit Card Identifier# on the Sims card
You may want to have land line phone following there instructions if your transferring from existing phone
The process takes less than five minutes
Expect your new phone to go through many reboots that day (4 to 6 times as I can remember to add software programming to the phone)
Once everything is done I was able to make calls, txt and browse the internet without any problems

Best Compromise for Me
First off, let me say that I have always preferred Motorola phones
In particular, I like the Moto actions that simplify use of the camera, flashlight, and notifications
Having said that, the problem over the last couple of years is that that Motorola has seemed to have forgotten how to make a phone, unless it crosses the line into being an oversized phablet
I miss the form factor and size of the original Moto X
It just felt good in your hand
And it easily fit into your front pocket
Even though the screen bezels have shrunken over time, and the fingerprint sensor has been moved to the back, does everyone want a 6

6 or larger phone that is tough to hold in average hands, or fit comfortably into your pocket?And Motorola seems to want to name have of its products Moto G this or Moto G that, like there aren't any other worthy letters in the alphabet (Ok, I know they have the budget Moto E series, but what happened to the beloved Moto X or the upper tier Moto Z?)
I determined that the Moto G Stylus was the smallest Moto phone released in 2020 (in order to have Android 10/11)
I find the stylus itself to be a gimmick on this phone

Why would you put a stylus on the smallest phone in the lineup?It makes no sense, as a stylus is more appropriate for the other Moto monsters, and leaving it out of the Moto G (ad nauseum) Stylus would have left some precious room for a larger battery or a better configuration for the poorly placed flash/camera setup
And the fingerprint sensor seems to be hit or miss (mostly miss)
Those are my gripes

As for my compliments, the Moto G Stylus (here we go again) has a nano SD slot for a good chunk of memory, USB-C port, headphone port, a nice camera, dual speakers, and a nice screen with unobtrusive punch hole selfie camera
It is a global phone with both GSM and CDMA connectivity, so I can take overseas and use by popping in another SIM card
And as I mentioned, offers the Moto Actions and a clean version of Android 10/11
All for around $200
I like the Gesma case paired with it, which protects it without adding too much bulk, and has the best camera/flash cutout design to address Moto's poor design here
Offer some phones, even one, that aren't so big
Give them decent memory and storage, nice cameras, USB-C, GSM and CDMA connectivity
Enable them with WiFi calling capability and keep your wonderful Moto Actions
Just dump the gimmicks
You have the makings for some real winners rather than lots of near misses

I bought this to replace an aging Android phone
After receiving this and having my phone service switched to this phone, I was pleasantly surprised even before putting service on it
This was by far the best Android phone I've had to date
This product was far and away the easiest Android phone I've set up
And yes, this is my first Moto phone
I came over from another manufacturer's phone
It wasn't nearly as well made nor easy to set up the fingerprint reader for one
The rest is standard Android fair
The battery life on this new phone is rather astounding
I can watch three movies on the phone, talk on Internet Relay Chat for hours, and do many things as well for 24 hours on a charge and often longer
Though this in part is due to a newer processor, it's also part of the phone design as well
Kudos to the Motorola engineers
As to the camera, I've only shot a few photos with it
Coming from 35mm film cameras, I can say this does a decent job for a phone camera
It won't compete to an old film camera nor will it compete with today's modern DSLR cameras
All in all, if you're looking for a new phone and don't have the budget for a top tier phone, this should be on your list for consideration
If you like as vanilla an Android operating system as possible (not skinned), this is another reason to put this phone on your list

TO ALL SPRINT USERS
To all Sprint users, the SIM card you need is the SIMOLW416TQ SIM card
As of Dec'2020, the SIMOLW516TQ SIM card that they are issuing for this phone will not work even though their system shows that it is compatible
I've gone through the activation process, getting the confirmation email, but kept on getting the invalid/locked SIM error on the phone
I've spent hours on chat and phone through their so-call advanced trouble shooting but they were not able to get the SIMOLW516TQ SIM card to work
My advice is to see if you can get the SIMOLW416TQ SIM card before purchasing this phone since it's hard to find (got mines from a seller on here)
It will save you a lot of headache
Once you have the SIM card, you can activate the phone via the sprint online activation process without any problems
Apart from that, it's definitely a good budget phone

Slow Phone with Long Battery Life
Been using different brands of smartphones over the years and switching to new ones every two years or so
This one is my latest purchase after careful online research and also positive reviews
The camera and original app combo is definitely below standard
Picture and video qualities are comparable to my older phones from half decade ago
Auto focus is bad, flash photography is bad, auto white balance is also bad
Wide angle cam?Not existing!Even after installing different camera apps, the results are often mediocre at best
The fingerprint sensor works about 60 percent of the time
That means having to manually type in code to unlock phone whenever it doesn't work correctly
I found this to be an issue under cold weather conditions, when slight moisture is present, and after application of hand sanitizers
The processing power of this device cannot handle more than a couple of apps running simultaneously
For example, when downloading a file via Google Chrome while searching for nearby fuel stations via Gasbuddy
Not only it's slow, even at full 4G LTE reception, it sometimes locks up when using certain apps while others are open in the background
Video chat and sound qualities are okay but not great as described in some reviews
I use couple different apps for video conferencing and been told that brightness/glare and focusing are the most common problems
If you keep this phone for emergency or light use, I'd say it's a good choice
If you plan on using your smartphone for work, daily online shopping, banking, and/or navigation, then I'd highly recommend seeking another device

Disappointing Offering From the Moto G series
I've owned two previous Moto G phones
The original and the G4
Both were very good bargains that had few compromises when compared to phones that were 3 times as expensive
The latest Moto G phone is a bit less satisfying
It was also limited to GSM, so when I switched carriers I used my wife's old iPhone 7 for a few months until I purchases the Moto G Stylus
I'll use the phones as reference for my review
Great for playing games and watching videos
Clarity is great
Much better pixel and color quality than either of the two phones I mentioned
The iPhone 7 might have had better pixel specs, but the screen is so small it doesn't compete
Camera - The camera is definitely fantastic
Better than any phone I have owned in the past
Processor - The 6XX series snapdragon is a step up from previous Gs and is solid, if not spectacular
Can play most games very well on Medium quality settings
That weight comes with a stylus and a respectable battery, but it's still much bigger than I was expecting
Not very comfortable from one-handed use, and seems a bit clunky when I have it up to my ear for calls
Wireless buds help with that problem, but I'm simply surprised by how massive and clunky this thing is
My Mate SE is a similar size, but is extremely thin and light with an all-day battery
Screen - Although the size and clarity are great, the responsiveness is the worst of any device (phone/table/palm pilot/toy) that I have ever owned
There are spots around each corner that require multiple taps to respond
I'm wondering if my phone is simply defective, or if it's normal
Stylus - The stylus is an interesting novelty, and along with the screen was the main reason I bought the phone over the iPhone SE
I didn't expect to be able to write on the phone like a Samsung NOTE device, but I thought I could still use it as a note-taking tool using the swipe keyboard and the OneNote app
All in all, I think the stylus is really a neutral option
I probably wouldn't buy a phone with one again
I thought I would find multiple reasons to use it, but in reality it's relatively benign, and just adds to the size of the beast
Performance - As previously stated, the performance is simply good
What I am most surprised by, however, is how much better the old iPhone 7 worked
For example, the MOTO G takes between 5-15 seconds to load/refresh my Mint or Etrade apps
The iPhone 7 was nearly instant
I didn't expect a brand new 6XX snapdragon to lag that far behind a 4 year old iPhone
User Interface - Previous versions of the G enjoyed nearly stock versions of Android
For some reason Moto decided to screw that up, and add a bunch of useless quirks and reminders that result in some apps not working properly
Fragmentation will be the end of Android someday
I don't know why phone manufacturers don't get that
It is well priced and offered for free at some discount carriers, so it's hard to complain
Can't say I regret it, but can't say I would recommend it either
Especially considering the screen issues, which may be a defect
With the iPhone SE and the Pixel 4A, however, there are far better low priced options right now

Works and is fully supported on T-Mobile
This phone was purchased after a lot of research because T-Mobile is shutting down some parts of their network to repurpose the frequencies for other uses
This has resulted in my old phone not being able to function on the network starting early next year
It took me a lot of research to identify a suitable replacement
In the past I have never paid attention to technical details of a phone such as the frequency bands it supports, etc
But you have to if you plan to use this device on T-Mobile
This device supports the important 4G bands that T-Mobile uses, 2, 4, 5, 12, 66 and 71
The last one, 71, is particularly hard to find on many cheap unlocked handsets, especially from chinese brands like Xiaomi, OnePlus, Oppo, etc
Major brands like Samsung support it, but sometimes only on handsets made for the US market, not the international versions (which are often cheaper and have additional features like dual-sim)
I had to settle for this model even though it did not have some of the features I like in a phone at this price-point, such as dual-sim and NFC
It is a shame how much manufacturers cripple a device just because they support one important feature that their competitors in the price range do not
Because they can get away with it
Mostly stock android with only a few moto-specific apps and featuresThe device feels solid and has an aluminum frameThe screen is very good, good size, good brightness, good pixel density
High screen to body ratio, decent colorsThe touch screen is very responsiveVery good amount of system memory and RAM
You will not run out of space for your apps, photos, music, etc

GPS has alternatives like GLONASS and Galileo, so you are not restricted to the use of US GPS satellitesIf you prefer using a stylus on a regular basis or for fine work, this is one of the few devices with a stylus built-inMost importantly, I used the IMEI check on TMobile's website, and this phone is fully supported with all the latest features and capabilities such as VoLTE, etc
It is splash-resistant, so you should be ok if the phone gets a few drops of water on it due to rain, etc
If you are an avid gamer with a penchant for high frame-rate games, this is probably not the ideal device for youThe screen is IPS LCD, not AMOLED
And the refresh rate is only 60 Hz

Many newer devices have moved on to 90 Hz and some high-end devices are setting the standard with 120 Hz and 144 Hz displaysThere is face unlock, but it is not offered as the default - mainly because it is 2D face recognition, so it is less secure and can be fooled by using an actual-size photo of you, for exampleThe hole-punch selfie camera can be a bit of a distraction since it draws your eyes towards itself when you are looking at something like a youtube video in full-screen mode
I would have preferred a thin top bezel for the selfie camera, notification LED, etc

And speaking of notification LED, there is noneSame goes for NFC and dual-simThe camera is not great in low-light conditions - it is not bad, but depending on the conditions, it can over-expose bright areas and make the dark areas completely black, or it can make the picture grainy
And the stylus itself is not an electronic device with its own smarts - you can use any stylus with the phone

The only advantage of this stylus is that it fits in the phone's stylus slot so that you don't have to carry it around separatelyMotorola has a habit of not updating android versions on their devices frequently or on a timely fashion, so I don't expect this device to get past Android 11 - this is a future criticism and I would be happy to be proved wrong!Overall, I like the device so far
It is in the correct price range (I don't want to spend more than $100/year on a cellphone, and I have never managed to hold onto a device for more than 3 years, so $300 is my upper limit for price)
It has full support for my carrier, which is a very important consideration

The features on this phone are par for the course when it comes to devices in its price range, so even though I have listed many cons, it is mostly a wishlist that I wish can be accommodated on a sub-$300 phone rather than just the high-end devices
If you have specific questions about the device, please post as a comment and I will try to answer them

My Moto g5 was getting a bit long in the tooth
I had to carry around an external battery pack to make it through the day
BTW on a separate note, you might want to think twice before hooking your $1000 Samsung or iPhone up to a $5 no name charger
While looking into ways to try to prolong the life of my Moto g5 I came across a number of articles and reports about the negative impact low quality chargers can have your battery and phone
Anyway on o the phone review
I'm recently retired, but while working my company used to provide our phones
I always went with the Samsung Note
I found having a stylus very handy
When I saw this new offering from Motorola I decided it give it a try as I really couldn't justify $1000 for a cell phoneFirst, call quality and signal quality are excellent
My wife got an iPhone 11 right after I got my Moto
We travel a lot and one area that we go to has notoriously bad reception, so it was a good test
The Moto rivaled the iPhone in this area
Build Quality is OK, the indigo case looks cool, but it really doesn't matter because the first this I did was order a case for it
The iPhone is substantially heavier, but then again it's case is glass
Not a great idea for someone like me
Display - The display is clear with good color
And even thought the iPhone specs blow the doors off the Moto's,I didn't see a lot of difference initially
As I used my wife's phone more (I'm the family Tech support)I came to realize that the iPhone display is noticeably brighter and crisper
Not that the Moto display is bad
I have watched plenty of Netflix and Hulu on it with no complaints

Speakers - I was actually surprised at how loud the phone is when playing movies and if you're not super picky ( which I am) about your music quality, you could even listen to music on it w/o Bluetooth speakers
Stylus - Ok it's not a Samsung Note, but it's not $1000 either
It's not an active stylus so there is no palm rejection, but once you get used to that, it works very well
I love that when you pop the stylus out, the Moto note app starts up w/o having to unlock the phone
Camera - As a Photo hobbyist the camera specs interested me but it was not a deal maker or breaker
I own 5 cameras, ranging from pocket sized super zooms up to a Canon DSLR and I usually have one of them with me
But I have to say I've been impressed with the Phone's Camera when Ihave used it
If you have a normal amount of room light the indoor pictures with ambient light are excellent, very natural
The night vision is very good for a camera in this price range
Video was barely discernable from the video I take on my Canon g-16
And the wide angle action cam comes in handy

Normally I rarely use a cameras built in filters or effects, preferring to post-produce in LightRoom or PhotoShop, but I did play around a bit with the cameras filters, putting my 2 grand daughters, who dressed as Leia and Rei for Halloween on Tatooine before posting them to Facebook
And Portrait mode iw very effective, althoughit settings are somewhat lacking in explanation/documentation
The only issues that I have had with the phone are more AT&T issues than phone issues
The Phone is capable of VoIP, and if you buy an AT&T Moto g Stylus it supported
I have to use Google Voice VoIP when in the weak signal area I mentioned above
Kind of a PIA#2 - VoLTE - The phone supports it, It will be required by all carries in the near future, AT&T's own documentation says they support it on the unlocked Moto g Stylus
I spent several hours with AT&T tech support getting it enabled
In they end they weren't even sure if they had enabled it
I ended up downloading a 3rd party phone network analyzer and was able to determine that VoLTE was enabled even though ther was no way to verify it on the phone natively
In summary - it's a great phone for $200
If you have AT&T just be aware of the issues I mentioned here

So for the past year, I've had the Redmi Note 8 Pro, and it's been a solid phone, so I decided to upgrade to the 9
Best Pre-5G Flagship Value at Mid-range Price
From a loyal LG customer, last was the LG V30 with amazing sound, video and camera quality
But the ram, memory and battery life started lacking
The Note 9 Pro beats it in spades
Battery life is the best part of the phone
I've had used it 3 days straight with mobile data constantly on before recharging
Never spent more than $300 on a phone as I always buy one or two generations behind
But it's not without its quirks
And it may be unfair to compare it to the 3 year old LG V30
Firstly it's a Chinese phone so there may be a security risk
Lately I've had emails from Venmo about unauthorized sign-ins since using the phone
But that could be another data breach
From a 3 year old Flagship LG V30 the Note 9 Pro is lacking
Can't control game graphics and frame rate like the V30 running on android 9
But it's moot since the battery is so big
One cool feature is running 2 apps in split screen top/bottom and 50/50 or 66/33 or 33/66 size
The V30 was able to do that
But you can drag an app out and have it float on a corner as a window
Also can't change the aspect ratio or the resolution of the screenThirdly, even though it's unlocked you have to make sure your carrier bands are supported
I'm with T-Mobile and most bands are supported but still had to create a custom APN (look it up) to send/receive txts and mms txts
The APN on my sim card was not fully compatible
Also if I don't keep mobile data on there's no guarantee of incoming/outgoing calls
But come January 2021 T-Mobile subscribers will only be able to make VoLTE calls
I also seem to get 3G speeds even though LTE is indicated is connected and indicated on status bar
If you dig around settings you can see downstream speeds on status bar
Looked everywhere but can't seem to find it
And can't send/receive txts over wifi which my old phone could do in case I didn't have a cell signal
And it's LCD not OLED like my old phone
Light does bleed thru on top right hand corner
Battery life and brightness is not an issue because the battery is big
I still prefer OLED for better blacks and grays and no light bleeding
Every generation LG phone allowed me to transfer and restore all my apps, accounts, email and settings with little follow up thru it's mobile app
It's the main reason I stuck with LG for so long
On the Redmi I was only able to transfer and restore my Google account and some apps
Had to sign in to most of my accounts again unlike the seamlessness of LG app/account restore process
I know I've focused on the negatives but the positives speak for themselves
For instance the rear camera is amazing at 64 mp and you can record 4k video if you have the memory
Either it will be another Redmi or I'll go back to LG when the price is right
Forgot to mention no wireless charging and it's not waterproof, the V30 has it
But there is a headphone jack
Side note, when I read reviews I usually read the bad reviews first that's why the review skews negative but it isn't so
There are many features that are not covered more readily explained from other reviews so I won't be repeating them
